Virtual-Voltage Partition-Based Approach to Optimal Transmission Switching

Chin-Yao Chang  Sonia Martínez  Jorge Cortés C.-Y. Chang, S. Martínez, and J. Cortés are with the Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, UC San Diego. A preliminary version of this work appeared as [1] at the 2017 Allerton Conference on Communications, Control, and Computing.
Abstract

This paper deals with optimal transmission switching (OTS) problems involving discrete binary decisions about network topology and non-convex power flow constraints. We adopt a semidefinite programming formulation for the OPF problem which, however, remains nonconvex due to the presence of discrete variables and bilinear products between the decision variables. To tackle the latter, we introduce a novel physically-inspired, virtual-voltage approximation that leads to provable lower and upper bounds on the solution of the original problem. To deal with the exponential complexity caused by the discrete variables, we introduce a graph partition-based algorithm which breaks the problem into several parallel mixed-integer subproblems of smaller size. Simulations demonstrate the high degree of accuracy and affordable computational requirements of our approach.

I Introduction

Optimal transmission switching (OTS) is concerned with the identification of power grid topologies that minimize generation cost while maintaining the secure operation of the grid. This leads to a class of non-convex optimization problems with discrete decision variables and bilinear constraints. Solving OTS has the potential to yield significant benefits in efficiency and reliability while respecting security constraints, but the complexity of solving such highly non-convex problems makes achieving this goal difficult. Our focus here is on developing a computationally efficient approach to approximate the solution of OTS problems.

Literature review: Discrete variables appear in optimal power flow (OPF) problems in many ways, such as transmission switching and post-contingency controls. The works [2, 3, 4] provide surveys on the solution of OPF problems with discrete variables. Many of the methods employed to solve OPF problems have been extended to deal with mixed-integer OPF, e.g., particle swarm optimization [5, 6] and genetic algorithms [7]. Transmission line switching or network topology reconfiguration commonly serve as corrective mechanisms in response to system contingencies see [8, 9] and references therein. In [10, 11, 12], linearized OPF, also known as DCOPF, is deployed to solve OTS efficiently. Despite its relative low complexity, DCOPF may lead, especially in congested systems, to poor solutions that can even result in voltage collapse [13, 14]. The work [15] proposes quadratic convex (QC) relaxations for the MIP-OPF problem, which provides more accurate results than DCOPF, while still retaining a fast computation time. Recent studies [15, 16] show that methods based on semidefinite programming (SDP) convex relaxations of ACOPF may lead to better solutions than DCOPF and QC. However, how to handle variables for transmission switching in the context of SDP is challenging and not fully understood. The challenges stem from not only from the integer-valued nature of these variables, but also from the presence of bilinear terms involving the product of discrete decision variables with continuous ones, reflecting the impact on the physical modeling of the line being connected. The paper [16] uses a lift-and-branch-and-bound procedure to deal with the SDP formulation of mixed-integer OPF (OTS as a special case), but has still exponential complexity in the worst case due to the nature of the branch-and-bound procedure. The work [17] also uses SDP to solve OTS problems, where bilinear terms associated to line connections are addressed by assuming certain nominal network topology and bilinear terms of other discrete decision variables are dealt with using the McCormick relaxation [18].

Statement of contributions: We consider the OTS problem and introduce a novel SDP convex relaxation to approximate its solution. Our contributions are twofold. First, we introduce a novel way of dealing with the nonconvexity coming from the presence of bilinear terms, which we term virtual-voltage approximation. Our approach is based on introducing virtual-voltage variables for the terminal nodes of each switchable line and impose physically-meaningful constraints on them. We show that this approach leads to sound bounds on individual flows of the switchable lines, and provides lower and upper bounds on the optimal value of the original problem. Our second contribution deals with the nonconvexity coming from the discrete variables. We build on the virtual-voltage approximation to propose a graph partition-based algorithm that significantly reduces the computational complexity of solving the original problem. This algorithm uses the values of the optimal dual variables from the virtual-voltage method to define a weighted network graph, which is then partitioned with a minimum weight edge-cut set. The algorithm breaks the original network into sub-networks so as to minimize the correlation between the solutions to the optimization problem on each sub-network. Finally, the algorithm solves the OTS problem on each sub-network in parallel and combines them to reconstruct the solution of the original problem. We implement the proposed algorithms on various IEEE standard test cases, and compare them with available approaches from the literature to illustrate their superior performance regarding convergence to the optima and computation time.

II-1 Graph Theory

We review basic notions of graph theory following [19]. A graph is a pair 𝒢=(𝒩,ℰ)𝒢𝒩ℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}=(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}},\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}), where 𝒩⊆ℕ𝒩ℕ\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\subseteq\operatorname{\mathbb{N}} is the set of nodes and ℰ⊆𝒩×𝒩ℰ𝒩𝒩\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}\subseteq\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\times\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} is the set of edges. A self-loop is an edge that connects a node to itself. The graph is undirected if {i,k}={k,i}∈ℰ𝑖𝑘𝑘𝑖ℰ\{i,k\}=\{k,i\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}. A path is a sequence of nodes such that any two consecutive nodes correspond to an edge. The graph is connected if there exists a path between any two nodes. An orientation of an undirected graph is an assignment of exactly one direction to each of its edges. A graph is simple if it does not have self-loops or multiple edges connecting any pair of nodes. Throughout the paper, we limit our discussion to undirected, simple graphs. A vertex-induced subgraph of 𝒢𝒢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}, written 𝒢⁡[𝒩s]=(𝒩s,ℰs)𝒢subscript𝒩𝑠subscript𝒩𝑠subscriptℰ𝑠\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}[\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s}]=(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s},\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}), satisfies 𝒩s⊆𝒩subscript𝒩𝑠𝒩\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s}\subseteq\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} and ℰs=ℰ∩(𝒩s×𝒩s)subscriptℰ𝑠ℰsubscript𝒩𝑠subscript𝒩𝑠\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}=\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}\cap(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s}\times\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s}). An edge cut set is a subset of edges which, if removed, disconnects the graph. A weighted graph is a graph where each branch {i,k}𝑖𝑘\{i,k\} has a weight, wi​k∈+subscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘absentw_{ik}\in_{+}. Given the edge weights w∈+|ℰ|superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑤absentw\in_{+}^{|\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}|}, the adjacency matrix A𝐴A has A​(i,k)=A​(k,i)=wi​k𝐴𝑖𝑘𝐴𝑘𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖𝑘A(i,k)=A(k,i)=w_{ik} if {i,k}∈ℰ𝑖𝑘ℰ\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}, and A​(i,k)=0𝐴𝑖𝑘0A(i,k)=0 otherwise. The degree matrix D𝐷D is a diagonal matrix such that D​(i,i)=∑k,{i,k}∈ℰwi​k𝐷𝑖𝑖subscript𝑘𝑖𝑘ℰsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑘D(i,i)=\sum_{k,\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}w_{ik}. The normalized adjacency matrix is An=D−1​A​D−1subscript𝐴𝑛superscript𝐷1𝐴superscript𝐷1A_{n}=\sqrt{D}^{-1}A\sqrt{D}^{-1}. The Laplacian matrix is L=D−A𝐿𝐷𝐴L=D-A. The Laplacian matrix is positive semidefinite, with zero as an eigenvalue and multiplicity equal to the number of connected components in the graph. The Fiedler vector is the eigenvector associated with the second smallest eigenvalue of L𝐿L. An n𝑛n-partition of a connected 𝒢=(𝒩,ℰ,A)𝒢𝒩ℰ𝐴\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}=(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}},\operatorname{\mathcal{E}},A) divides 𝒢𝒢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}} into a number of n𝑛n connected vertex-induced subgraphs, 𝒢⁡[𝒱i]𝒢subscript𝒱𝑖\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}[\operatorname{\mathcal{V}}_{i}], such that ∪i=1n𝒱i=𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝒱𝑖𝒩\cup_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname{\mathcal{V}}_{i}=\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} and 𝒱i∩𝒱k=∅subscript𝒱𝑖subscript𝒱𝑘\operatorname{\mathcal{V}}_{i}\cap\operatorname{\mathcal{V}}_{k}=\emptyset for all i≠k𝑖𝑘i\neq k. An n𝑛n-optimal partition of 𝒢=(𝒩,ℰ,A)𝒢𝒩ℰ𝐴\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}=(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}},\operatorname{\mathcal{E}},A) is an n𝑛n-partition of 𝒢𝒢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}} with ∑{i,k}∈ℰcwi​ksubscript𝑖𝑘subscriptℰ𝑐subscript𝑤𝑖𝑘\sum_{\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{c}}w_{ik} minimized, where ℰc=ℰ∖(∪i=1n𝒱i×𝒱i)subscriptℰ𝑐ℰsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝒱𝑖subscript𝒱𝑖\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{c}=\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}\setminus(\cup_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname{\mathcal{V}}_{i}\times\operatorname{\mathcal{V}}_{i}). Spectral graph partitioning partitions a connected graph 𝒢𝒢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}} into two vertex-induced subgraphs, 𝒢⁡[𝒩1]𝒢subscript𝒩1\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}[\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{1}] and 𝒢⁡[𝒩2]𝒢subscript𝒩2\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}[\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{2}], where 𝒩1subscript𝒩1\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{1} and 𝒩2subscript𝒩2\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{2} are the nodes corresponding to the positive and non-positive entries of the Fiedler vector, respectively.

II-2 McCormick Relaxation of Bilinear Terms

The McCormick envelopes [18] provide linear relaxations for optimization problems that involve bilinear terms. Consider a bilinear term x​y𝑥𝑦xy on the variables x,y∈𝑥𝑦absentx,y\in, for which there exist upper and lower bounds, x¯≤x≤x¯,y¯≤y≤y¯formulae-sequence¯𝑥𝑥¯𝑥¯𝑦𝑦¯𝑦\underline{x}\leq x\leq\overline{x},\quad\underline{y}\leq y\leq\overline{y}. The McCormick relaxation consists of substituting in the optimization problem the term x​y𝑥𝑦xy by its surrogate v∈𝑣absentv\in and adding the following McCormick envelopes on v𝑣v,

v≥x¯​y+x​y¯−x¯​y¯,v≥x¯​y+x​y¯−x¯​y¯,formulae-sequence𝑣¯𝑥𝑦𝑥¯𝑦¯𝑥¯𝑦𝑣¯𝑥𝑦𝑥¯𝑦¯𝑥¯𝑦\displaystyle v\geq\underline{x}y+x\underline{y}-\underline{x}\underline{y},\quad v\geq\overline{x}y+x\overline{y}-\overline{x}\overline{y}, (1a)
v≤x¯​y+x​y¯−x¯​y¯,v≤x​y¯+x¯​y−x¯​y¯.formulae-sequence𝑣¯𝑥𝑦𝑥¯𝑦¯𝑥¯𝑦𝑣𝑥¯𝑦¯𝑥𝑦¯𝑥¯𝑦\displaystyle v\leq\overline{x}y+x\underline{y}-\overline{x}\underline{y},\quad v\leq x\overline{y}+\underline{x}y-\underline{x}\overline{y}. (1b)

Constraints (1) are tight, in the sense that each plane in (1) is tangent to the bilinear-constraint manifold at two boundary lines. The convex polyhedron in the variables (x,y,v)𝑥𝑦𝑣(x,y,v) encloses the actual bilinear-constraint manifold.

III Problem Statement

We begin with the formulation of the OPF problem over an electrical network and its SDP convex relaxation following [20]. Then, we introduce binary variables leading to the OTS problem formulation of interest in this paper.

For convenience, V={Vi|i∈𝒩}𝑉conditional-setsubscript𝑉𝑖𝑖𝒩V=\{V_{i}\;|\;i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\} denotes the collection of voltages at all buses. In the OTS problem, the set of transmission lines ℰ0subscriptℰ0\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{0} is divided into a set of switchable ℰssubscriptℰ𝑠\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s} and non-switchable ℰℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{E}} lines such that ℰ0=ℰs∪ℰsubscriptℰ0subscriptℰ𝑠ℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{0}=\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}\cup\operatorname{\mathcal{E}} (note that ℰs=ℰ0subscriptℰ𝑠subscriptℰ0\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}=\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{0} and ℰ=∅ℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}=\emptyset is possible). Choosing among the switchable lines which ones are active affects the nodal active and reactive power injections in (6c). The question is then to determine what the optimal choice of switching lines is. We formalize this problem next. For each line {i,k}∈ℰs𝑖𝑘subscriptℰ𝑠\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}, we define a binary variable αi​k∈{0,1}subscript𝛼𝑖𝑘01\alpha_{ik}\in\{0,1\}, and we say the line is connected if αi​k=1subscript𝛼𝑖𝑘1\alpha_{ik}=1 and disconnected otherwise. If αi​k=1subscript𝛼𝑖𝑘1\alpha_{ik}=1, then the power flow from node i𝑖i to k𝑘k through edge {i,k}∈ℰs𝑖𝑘subscriptℰ𝑠\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s} is

Pi​k=𝐓𝐫⁡{Yi​k​W},Qi​k=𝐓𝐫⁡{Y¯i​k​W},formulae-sequencesubscript𝑃𝑖𝑘𝐓𝐫subscript𝑌𝑖𝑘𝑊subscript𝑄𝑖𝑘𝐓𝐫subscript¯𝑌𝑖𝑘𝑊\displaystyle P_{ik}=\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{Y_{ik}W\},\quad Q_{ik}=\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{\overline{Y}_{ik}W\}, (7)

Here yi​k∈ℂsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑘ℂy_{ik}\in\mathbb{C} is the admittance of line {i,k}𝑖𝑘\{i,k\}. Taking (7) into account, the active and reactive power of each node become

Pi=𝐓𝐫⁡{Yi​W}+PDi+∑k∈𝒮iαi​k​Pi​k,subscript𝑃𝑖𝐓𝐫subscript𝑌𝑖𝑊subscript𝑃subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑘subscript𝒮𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖𝑘subscript𝑃𝑖𝑘\displaystyle P_{i}=\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{Y_{i}W\}+P_{D_{i}}+\sum\nolimits_{k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{i}}\alpha_{ik}P_{ik}, (8)

where 𝒮i:={k|{i,k}∈ℰs}assignsubscript𝒮𝑖conditional-set𝑘𝑖𝑘subscriptℰ𝑠\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{i}:=\{k\;|\;\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}\}. Given α∈{0,1}|ℰs|𝛼superscript01subscriptℰ𝑠\alpha\in\{0,1\}^{|{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}_{s}|}, we use (P1)-α𝛼\alpha to refer to the OPF problem solved with the network topology with extra lines as determined by α𝛼\alpha.

We are interested in solving what we call (P2), which is the optimization (P1) with constraints (6a) and (6b) replaced by (7) and (8). In addition to the optimization of the power flow, this formulation incorporates the optimal choice among the switchable lines in ℰssubscriptℰ𝑠\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}. The problem (P2) is non-convex for two reasons: the binary variables αi​ksubscript𝛼𝑖𝑘\alpha_{ik} and the bilinear products of αi​ksubscript𝛼𝑖𝑘\alpha_{ik} and W𝑊W. The first problem can be addressed using existing integer-programming solvers [22, 17]. The McCormick relaxation described in Section II-2 is the standard way to deal with the second problem. In this paper, we instead provide alternative routes to address each of these problems for the optimization (P2).

Remark III.1.

(Networks where all lines are switchable). General formulations of the OTS problem assume all transmission lines are switchable, see e.g. [23, 15]. Some works also pre-select a pool of switchable lines through heuristic methods [23]. The approach described next is applicable to both types of scenarios. □□\square

IV Virtual-Voltage Approximation of Bilinear Terms

We introduce here a novel way to deal with the bilinear terms in (P2) which we term virtual-voltage approximation. We start by noting that every binary variable α𝛼\alpha only appears in the bilinear products in (8) together with another continuous variable W𝑊W. If we convexify the binary variables by having them take values in [0,1]01[0,1], then we can interpret each bilinear term corresponding to {i,k}∈ℰs𝑖𝑘subscriptℰ𝑠\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s} as a line power flow from i𝑖i to k𝑘k, with the magnitude bounded by what W𝑊W indicates. Following this reasoning, if the direction of power flow of every line {i,k}∈ℰs𝑖𝑘subscriptℰ𝑠\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s} was known, then the bilinear term would no longer be an issue. For example, if we knew that Pi​k=𝐓𝐫⁡{Yi​k​W}∈+subscript𝑃𝑖𝑘𝐓𝐫subscript𝑌𝑖𝑘𝑊subscriptabsentP_{ik}=\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{Y_{ik}W\}\in_{+} and Qi​k=𝐓𝐫⁡{Y¯i​k​W}∈+subscript𝑄𝑖𝑘𝐓𝐫subscript¯𝑌𝑖𝑘𝑊subscriptabsentQ_{ik}=\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{\overline{Y}_{ik}W\}\in_{+}, then we could define new variables, P^i​k∈subscript^𝑃𝑖𝑘absent\hat{P}_{ik}\in and Q^i​k∈subscript^𝑄𝑖𝑘absent\hat{Q}_{ik}\in, replacing αi​k​Pi​ksubscript𝛼𝑖𝑘subscript𝑃𝑖𝑘\alpha_{ik}P_{ik} and αi​k​Qi​ksubscript𝛼𝑖𝑘subscript𝑄𝑖𝑘\alpha_{ik}Q_{ik} in (8), respectively, and impose

0≤P^i​k≤Pi​k,0≤Q^i​k≤Qi​k.formulae-sequence0subscript^𝑃𝑖𝑘subscript𝑃𝑖𝑘0subscript^𝑄𝑖𝑘subscript𝑄𝑖𝑘\displaystyle 0\leq\hat{P}_{ik}\leq P_{ik},\quad 0\leq\hat{Q}_{ik}\leq Q_{ik}. (9)

This would eliminate the bilinear terms and the only remaining non-convexity would be that the physical feasible solution should satisfy P^i​k∈{0,Pi​k}subscript^𝑃𝑖𝑘0subscript𝑃𝑖𝑘\hat{P}_{ik}\in\{0,P_{ik}\} and Q^i​k∈{0,Qi​k}subscript^𝑄𝑖𝑘0subscript𝑄𝑖𝑘\hat{Q}_{ik}\in\{0,Q_{ik}\}. In general, however, the direction of power flow of the lines {i,k}∈ℰs𝑖𝑘subscriptℰ𝑠\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s} is not known a priori and, hence, the trivial convex constraints (9) for the relaxation are no longer valid.

IV-A Convex Relaxation Via Virtual Voltages

Our idea to approximate each bilinear term builds on defining a virtual-voltage for the terminal nodes of the line and impose constraints on them to make sure they have physical sense. We make this precise next. Let ℰ^ssubscript^ℰ𝑠\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}_{s} be an arbitrary orientation of ℰssubscriptℰ𝑠\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}. To define the virtual-voltages, and in keeping with the SDP approach, for each {i,k}∈ℰ^s𝑖𝑘subscript^ℰ𝑠\{i,k\}\in\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}_{s} we introduce a two-by-two positive semidefinite matrix Ui​k∈𝕊+2subscript𝑈𝑖𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝕊2U_{ik}\in\operatorname{\mathbb{S}}^{2}_{+}. This matrix encodes physically meaningful voltages at the terminal nodes if its rank is one, namely, Ui​k=ui​k​ui​k⊤subscript𝑈𝑖𝑘subscript𝑢𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘topU_{ik}=u_{ik}u_{ik}^{\top}, with ui​k​(1)subscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1u_{ik}(1) and ui​k​(2)subscript𝑢𝑖𝑘2u_{ik}(2) corresponding to the voltages of nodes i𝑖i and k𝑘k, respectively. For convenience, we introduce M^=[1−1−11]^𝑀delimited-[]1111\hat{M}=[\begin{smallmatrix}1&-1\\ -1&1\end{smallmatrix}] and impose the following constraints on Ui​ksubscript𝑈𝑖𝑘U_{ik}

Ui​k​(1,1)subscript𝑈𝑖𝑘11\displaystyle U_{ik}(1,1) ≤𝐓𝐫⁡{Mi​W},absent𝐓𝐫subscript𝑀𝑖𝑊\displaystyle\leq\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{M_{i}W\}, (10a)
Ui​k​(2,2)subscript𝑈𝑖𝑘22\displaystyle U_{ik}(2,2) ≤𝐓𝐫⁡{Mk​W},absent𝐓𝐫subscript𝑀𝑘𝑊\displaystyle\leq\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{M_{k}W\}, (10b)
𝐓𝐫⁡{M^​Ui​k}𝐓𝐫^𝑀subscript𝑈𝑖𝑘\displaystyle\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{\hat{M}U_{ik}\} ≤𝐓𝐫⁡{Mi​k​W}.absent𝐓𝐫subscript𝑀𝑖𝑘𝑊\displaystyle\leq\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{M_{ik}W\}. (10c)

Constraints (10a) and (10b) ensure that the voltage magnitudes of i𝑖i and k𝑘k derived from Ui​ksubscript𝑈𝑖𝑘U_{ik} are no bigger than the ones from W𝑊W. Constraint (10c) ensures that the voltage difference between nodes i𝑖i and k𝑘k computed from Ui​ksubscript𝑈𝑖𝑘U_{ik} is less than the corresponding difference from W𝑊W. Therefore, if the matrix Ui​ksubscript𝑈𝑖𝑘U_{ik} has rank one, constraints (10) ensure that we obtain physically meaningful and feasible voltage values.

Let Y^i​k∈ℂ2×2subscript^𝑌𝑖𝑘superscriptℂ22\hat{Y}_{ik}\in\mathbb{C}^{2\times 2} be the principal sub-matrix of Yi​ksubscript𝑌𝑖𝑘Y_{ik} by only keeping the rows and columns associated with nodes i𝑖i and k𝑘k. For all practical purposes, the result of Lemma IV.1 implies that the matrix Ui​kopt3superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑘subscriptopt3U_{ik}^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}} specifies well-defined virtual-voltages at the terminal nodes, as we explain next.

Remark IV.2.

(Optimal solutions have well-defined virtual voltages). Using Lemma IV.1, we justify that the optimal solution Ui​kopt3superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑘subscriptopt3U_{ik}^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}} has a dominant eigenvalue as follows. The denominator of (12) is always non-negative due to (10c). The order of the denominator of (12) is at most 10−2superscript10210^{-2} as V¯i​k≈10−2subscript¯𝑉𝑖𝑘superscript102\overline{V}_{ik}\approx 10^{-2} in most test cases. On the other hand, when the virtual-voltage satisfies 𝐓𝐫⁡{M^​Ui​kopt3}≈𝐓𝐫⁡{Mi​Wopt3}𝐓𝐫^𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑘subscriptopt3𝐓𝐫subscript𝑀𝑖superscript𝑊subscriptopt3\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{\hat{M}U_{ik}^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}\}\approx\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{M_{i}W^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}\} or 𝐓𝐫⁡{M^​Ui​kopt3}≈𝐓𝐫⁡{Mk​Wopt3}𝐓𝐫^𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑘subscriptopt3𝐓𝐫subscript𝑀𝑘superscript𝑊subscriptopt3\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{\hat{M}U_{ik}^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}\}\approx\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{M_{k}W^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}\}, then the numerator is lower bounded by a scalar close to one, as V¯i≈1subscript¯𝑉𝑖1\underline{V}_{i}\approx 1. As a consequence, the fraction in (12) is usually bigger than 102superscript10210^{2}. Our simulations on IEEE 118 and 300 bus text cases confirm that ai​ksubscript𝑎𝑖𝑘a_{ik} is at least 100100100. □□\square

IV-B Physical Properties of the Convex Relaxation

The active and reactive power flows in (P3) on a switchable line {i,k}∈ℰs𝑖𝑘subscriptℰ𝑠\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s} are determined by Ui​ksubscript𝑈𝑖𝑘U_{ik} according to

Pi​kopt3=𝐓𝐫⁡{Y^i​k​Ui​kopt3},Qi​kopt3=𝐓𝐫⁡{Y¯^i​k​Ui​kopt3}.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑃subscriptopt3𝑖𝑘𝐓𝐫subscript^𝑌𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑘subscriptopt3subscriptsuperscript𝑄subscriptopt3𝑖𝑘𝐓𝐫subscript^¯𝑌𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑘subscriptopt3\displaystyle P^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}_{ik}=\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{\hat{Y}_{ik}U_{ik}^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}\},\quad Q^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}_{ik}=\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{\hat{\overline{Y}}_{ik}U_{ik}^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}\}. (13)

The next result shows that the optimal power losses on each edge are bounded by the ones computed from Wopt3superscript𝑊subscriptopt3W^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}.

Lemma IV.3.

(Bounds on the sums of line active and reactive powers). If the line charging susceptance is zero for all {i,k}∈ℰ^s𝑖𝑘subscript^ℰ𝑠\{i,k\}\in\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}_{s}, then the following inequalities hold

(14b)
Proof.

If the line charging susceptance is zero, then Yi​k+Yk​isubscript𝑌𝑖𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘𝑖Y_{ik}+Y_{ki} and Y¯i​k+Y¯k​isubscript¯𝑌𝑖𝑘subscript¯𝑌𝑘𝑖\overline{Y}_{ik}+\overline{Y}_{ki} take the following form

We next seek to upper bound the individual flows |Pi​k|subscript𝑃𝑖𝑘|P_{ik}| and |Pk​i|subscript𝑃𝑘𝑖|P_{ki}|. Our next result shows that, under certain conditions for (P3), stronger properties hold on the active power retrieved from the optimal solution Ui​kopt3superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑘subscriptopt3U_{ik}^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}} and Wopt3superscript𝑊subscriptopt3W^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}.

Condition (15) holds for most existing power systems [24]. An analogous result holds by restricting uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} instead.

Proposition IV.5.

(Bounds on directional power flow. II). If {i,k}∈ℰ^s𝑖𝑘subscript^ℰ𝑠\{i,k\}\in\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}_{s} is purely inductive, |ui|∈{0,wi}subscript𝑢𝑖0subscript𝑤𝑖|u_{i}|\in\{0,w_{i}\} and V¯i​ksubscript¯𝑉𝑖𝑘\overline{V}_{ik} is sufficiently small such that (15) holds, then (16) follows.

The proof of Proposition IV.5 is analogous to that of Proposition IV.4 and therefore we omit it. Similar bounds as (16) follow for reactive power if the sum of the cosine terms in the bracket of (18) is non-negative (however, in general, this is not the case). In addition, more involved, inequalities as (16) hold for the general impedance case, but we do not pursue them here. Propositions IV.4 and IV.5 show that, when the diagonal entries of Ui​kopt3superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑘subscriptopt3U_{ik}^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}} are at the boundary points of their constraints, (P3) eliminates the bilinear terms on the active line power flow of (P2) in the same way as (9). The difference between the relaxations is that there is no need in (P3) to know the direction of line power flow a priori, as opposed to (9).

IV-C Reconstructed Solution to the OTS Problem

We note that the ratio of the voltage magnitudes derived from Ui​kopt3superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑘subscriptopt3U_{ik}^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}} and Wopt3superscript𝑊subscriptopt3W^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}} provides an approximation of the discrete variables αi​ksubscript𝛼𝑖𝑘\alpha_{ik} in (8) as

α^i​k=𝐓𝐫⁡{Ui​kopt3}/𝐓𝐫⁡{Wi​kopt3}.subscript^𝛼𝑖𝑘𝐓𝐫subscriptsuperscript𝑈subscriptopt3𝑖𝑘𝐓𝐫subscriptsuperscript𝑊subscriptopt3𝑖𝑘\displaystyle\hat{\alpha}_{ik}=\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{U^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}_{ik}\}/\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{W^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}_{ik}\}. (21)

Note that α^∈[0,1]|ℰ^s|^𝛼superscript01subscript^ℰ𝑠\hat{\alpha}\in[0,1]^{|\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}_{s}|} because of (10). If we round the entries of α^^𝛼\hat{\alpha} to the closest number in {0,1}01\{0,1\}, we obtain a candidate solution α^r∈{0,1}|ℰ^s|subscript^𝛼𝑟superscript01subscript^ℰ𝑠\hat{\alpha}_{r}\in\{0,1\}^{|\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}_{s}|} to (P2). The following result, whose proof is straightforward, states the relationship between (P2) and (P3) based on the rounded solution α^rsubscript^𝛼𝑟\hat{\alpha}_{r}.

Proposition IV.6.

(Properties of the reconstructed solution). The optimal values of (P1)-α^rsubscript^𝛼𝑟\hat{\alpha}_{r}, (P2), and (P3) satisfy p1opt≥p2opt≥p3optsuperscriptsubscript𝑝1optsuperscriptsubscript𝑝2optsuperscriptsubscript𝑝3optp_{1}^{\operatorname{opt}}\geq p_{2}^{\operatorname{opt}}\geq p_{3}^{\operatorname{opt}}. Moreover, if p1opt=p3optsuperscriptsubscript𝑝1optsuperscriptsubscript𝑝3optp_{1}^{\operatorname{opt}}=p_{3}^{\operatorname{opt}}, then the optimal solution of (P1)-α^rsubscript^αr\hat{\alpha}_{r}, W1optsubscriptsuperscript𝑊opt1W^{\operatorname{opt}}_{1}, combined with α^rsubscript^𝛼𝑟\hat{\alpha}_{r}, is an optimal solution of (P2).

Note that even if α^=α^r∈{0,1}|ℰ^s|^𝛼subscript^𝛼𝑟superscript01subscript^ℰ𝑠\hat{\alpha}=\hat{\alpha}_{r}\in\{0,1\}^{|\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}_{s}|}, p3optsuperscriptsubscript𝑝3optp_{3}^{\operatorname{opt}} does not necessary equal p2optsuperscriptsubscript𝑝2optp_{2}^{\operatorname{opt}}. The reason is that (21) computes α^i​ksubscript^𝛼𝑖𝑘\hat{\alpha}_{ik} from the diagonal of Ui​kopt3subscriptsuperscript𝑈subscriptopt3𝑖𝑘U^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}_{ik}, and hence we can not conclude any equality for the off-diagonal elements of Ui​kopt3subscriptsuperscript𝑈subscriptopt3𝑖𝑘U^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}_{ik} and Wi​kopt3subscriptsuperscript𝑊subscriptopt3𝑖𝑘W^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}_{ik}. Hence, even if α^∈{0,1}|ℰ^s|^𝛼superscript01subscript^ℰ𝑠\hat{\alpha}\in\{0,1\}^{|\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}_{s}|}, the optimal solution of (P3) does not necessarily lie in the feasible region of (P2).

Remark IV.7.

(Comparison with the McCormick relaxation). We explain how we implement the McCormick relaxation on the problem (P2) for comparison purposes. For each {i,k}∈ℰ^s𝑖𝑘subscript^ℰ𝑠\{i,k\}\in\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}_{s}, we define new variables P^i​k,Q^i​k∈subscript^𝑃𝑖𝑘subscript^𝑄𝑖𝑘absent\hat{P}_{ik},\hat{Q}_{ik}\in to substitute the bilinear terms αi​k​Pi​k,αi​k​Qi​ksubscript𝛼𝑖𝑘subscript𝑃𝑖𝑘subscript𝛼𝑖𝑘subscript𝑄𝑖𝑘\alpha_{ik}P_{ik},\alpha_{ik}Q_{ik}, respectively. Then, we impose constraints of the form (1) on the new variables based on αi​k∈{0,1}subscript𝛼𝑖𝑘01\alpha_{ik}\in\{0,1\} and upper and lower bounds of active/reactive line power flow, P¯i​k,Q¯i​k∈+subscriptsubscript¯𝑃𝑖𝑘subscript¯𝑄𝑖𝑘absent\overline{P}_{ik},\overline{Q}_{ik}\in_{+}, P¯i​k=−P¯i​k,Q¯i​k=−Q¯i​kformulae-sequencesubscript¯𝑃𝑖𝑘subscript¯𝑃𝑖𝑘subscript¯𝑄𝑖𝑘subscript¯𝑄𝑖𝑘\underline{P}_{ik}=-\overline{P}_{ik},\underline{Q}_{ik}=-\overline{Q}_{ik}. If these bounds are far from the actual optimal line power flows, this can significantly affect the quality of the solution obtained by the McCormick relaxation, a point that we illustrate later in our simulations, along with rationale for how to select them. In contrast, the proposed relaxation (P3) is not sensitive to those line power bounds, as the virtual-voltages are bounded by the power computed from W𝑊W. Additionally, the variables P^i​ksubscript^𝑃𝑖𝑘\hat{P}_{ik} and Q^i​ksubscript^𝑄𝑖𝑘\hat{Q}_{ik} in the McCormick relaxation are loosely tied to the decision variable W𝑊W, whereas (P3) introduces constraints (10a)-(10c) enforcing a stronger physical connection between the virtual-voltages and W𝑊W. McCormick relaxation □□\square

IV-D N𝑁N-1 Security Constraints

The virtual-voltage approximation approach described above can also be applied to scenarios with security constraints. N𝑁N-1 security formulations are widely considered in the literature [25, 26, 27] and require that, under any single component outage (most commonly failures of a generator or a transmission line), power flow constraints remain satisfied. This prevents cascading failures and makes it easier to implement post-contingency controls. The proposed virtual-voltage approach can easily accommodate N𝑁N-1 security constraints as we explain next. Let 𝒞:={0,1,⋯,c}assign𝒞01⋯𝑐\operatorname{\mathcal{C}}:=\{0,1,\cdots,c\} be the set that enumerates contingency scenarios, with index t=0𝑡0t=0 corresponding to the nominal operating scenario. where ℰ[t]superscriptℰdelimited-[]𝑡\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}^{[t]} is the set of connected lines for contingency t∈𝒞𝑡𝒞t\in\operatorname{\mathcal{C}}. Each W[t]superscript𝑊delimited-[]𝑡W^{[t]} corresponds to the solution of the contingency t∈𝒞𝑡𝒞t\in\operatorname{\mathcal{C}}. All the constraints involved in (P3) are imposed on every W[t]superscript𝑊delimited-[]𝑡W^{[t]}. Since there is no coupling between W[t1]superscript𝑊delimited-[]subscript𝑡1W^{[t_{1}]} and W[t2]superscript𝑊delimited-[]subscript𝑡2W^{[t_{2}]} for different t1,t2∈𝒞subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2𝒞t_{1},t_{2}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{C}}, all the properties of the virtual-voltage approximation characterized above remain valid. The problem size of the security constrained OTS grows linearly with respect to |𝒞|𝒞|\operatorname{\mathcal{C}}|

V Partition-Based OTS Algorithm

The virtual-voltage approach described in Section IV finds a candidate switching, cf. (21) for the OTS problem. This, together with the solution to the convex relaxation (P3), provide upper and lower bounds on the optimal value of the OTS problem, cf. Proposition IV.6. Here, we discuss how to refine the reconstructed solution to better approximate the solution of the original optimization problem. One approach consists of using the branch-and-bound algorithm [28] and relying on (P3) to generate the required branch lower bounds in its execution. However, this approach can easily become intractable as the number of switchable lines grows because of the large number of cases where (P3) must be executed. Instead, we propose the partition-based OTS algorithm shown in Algorithm 1. The method relies on graph partitioning and is not directly applicable to security constrained OTS formulations, cf. Section IV-D.

V-1 Graph reduction

This is a step prior to graph partitioning which is motivated by the following observation. The graph partitioning should not result in nodes connected by a switchable line belonging to different subgraphs. This is because, if that were the case, then solving the OPF associated with each subgraph cannot capture how the switch in that specific line affects the optimal value of the original OTS problem. To address this, we ‘hide’ the nodes that are connected by ℰssubscriptℰ𝑠\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s} to the partitioning algorithm that finds the edge cut ℰcsubscriptℰ𝑐\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{c} so as to ensure ℰs∩ℰc=∅subscriptℰ𝑠subscriptℰ𝑐\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}\cap\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{c}=\emptyset. Let 𝒩s:={i∈𝒩|{i,k}∈ℰs}assignsubscript𝒩𝑠conditional-set𝑖𝒩𝑖𝑘subscriptℰ𝑠\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s}:=\{i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\;|\;\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}\} and let 𝒩s,isubscript𝒩𝑠𝑖\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s,i} be the set of nodes that are connected to node i∈𝒩s𝑖subscript𝒩𝑠i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s} through a line in ℰssubscriptℰ𝑠\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}. All nodes in 𝒩s,isubscript𝒩𝑠𝑖\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s,i} are clustered as one representative node and all the edges connected to one of 𝒩s,isubscript𝒩𝑠𝑖\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s,i} are considered being connected to the representative node. This results in a graph 𝒢r=((𝒩∖𝒩s)∪𝒱,ℰr)subscript𝒢𝑟𝒩subscript𝒩𝑠𝒱subscriptℰ𝑟\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}_{r}=\big{(}(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\setminus\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s})\cup\operatorname{\mathcal{V}},\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{r}\big{)}, where 𝒱𝒱\operatorname{\mathcal{V}} is the collection of representative nodes. Notice that ℰr⊆ℰsubscriptℰ𝑟ℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{r}\subseteq\operatorname{\mathcal{E}} and ℰrsubscriptℰ𝑟\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{r} is a strict subset of ℰℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{E}} if there is {i,k}∈ℰ𝑖𝑘ℰ\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}} such that a path connecting nodes i𝑖i and k𝑘k exists in the graph (𝒩,ℰs)𝒩subscriptℰ𝑠(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}},\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}). Figure 1 illustrates the construction of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}_{r} and has ℰr⊂ℰsubscriptℰ𝑟ℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{r}\subset\operatorname{\mathcal{E}} as one edge of ℰℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{E}} is dropped in the process of graph reduction.

The graph reduction step described above only makes sense when not all lines are switchable because otherwise, it results in a graph with a single node. For OTS scenarios where all lines are switchable, one can either skip the graph reduction step, or pre-select a set of lines that should remain non-switchable.

V-2 Graph partitioning

Our next step is to find an edge cut set ℰcsubscriptℰ𝑐\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{c} of the graph 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}_{r}. In order to minimally affect the optimal value poptsuperscript𝑝optp^{\operatorname{opt}}, the graph partitioning is based on the optimal dual variables of (P3). The optimum dual variables measure how the optimal value p3optsubscriptsuperscript𝑝opt3p^{\operatorname{opt}}_{3} of (P3) changes with respect to the corresponding constraint. With this interpretation, we define edge weights as follows

A​(i,k)={∑l∈{i,k}​λ¯lopt3+λ¯lopt3+γ¯lopt3+γ¯lopt3,{i,k}∈ℰr,0,otherwise.𝐴𝑖𝑘cases𝑙𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript¯𝜆𝑙subscriptopt3superscriptsubscript¯𝜆𝑙subscriptopt3superscriptsubscript¯𝛾𝑙subscriptopt3superscriptsubscript¯𝛾𝑙subscriptopt3𝑖𝑘subscriptℰ𝑟0otherwise\displaystyle A(i,k)=\begin{cases}\underset{l\in\{i,k\}}{\sum}\overline{\lambda}_{l}^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}+\underline{\lambda}_{l}^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}+\overline{\gamma}_{l}^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}}+\underline{\gamma}_{l}^{\operatorname{opt}_{3}},&\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{r},\\ 0,&\text{otherwise}.\end{cases}

Given the adjacency matrix A𝐴A, we do an n𝑛n-optimal partition on 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}_{r}, which gives 𝒢r⁡[𝒱10],⋯,𝒢r⁡[𝒱n0]subscript𝒢𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝒱01⋯subscript𝒢𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝒱0𝑛\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}_{r}[\operatorname{\mathcal{V}}^{0}_{1}],\cdots,\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}_{r}[\operatorname{\mathcal{V}}^{0}_{n}] with ∪i=1n𝒱i0=(𝒩∖𝒩s)∪𝒱superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝒱0𝑖𝒩subscript𝒩𝑠𝒱\cup_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname{\mathcal{V}}^{0}_{i}=(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\setminus\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s})\cup\operatorname{\mathcal{V}}. Since all the removed edges are in ℰℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}, we can use the same cut for the partition of 𝒢𝒢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}: 𝒢⁡[𝒱1],⋯,𝒢⁡[𝒱n]𝒢subscript𝒱1⋯𝒢subscript𝒱𝑛\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}[\operatorname{\mathcal{V}}_{1}],\cdots,\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}[\operatorname{\mathcal{V}}_{n}] with ∪i=1n𝒱i=𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝒱𝑖𝒩\cup_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname{\mathcal{V}}_{i}=\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}. Such partition ensures ℰc∩ℰs=∅subscriptℰ𝑐subscriptℰ𝑠\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{c}\cap\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}=\emptyset. The intuition is that the cut minimally perturbs poptsuperscript𝑝optp^{\operatorname{opt}} because it select edges with minimal weight for the weighted graph (𝒢,A)𝒢𝐴(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}},A).

Finding the optimal cut set is NP-hard. There are algorithms [29, 30] that can approximate it in a few seconds for graphs of the order of a thousand nodes. However, they do not guarantee that the resulting subgraphs are connected. To ensure this property, we resort to spectral graph partitioning.

Theorem V.1.

(Fiedler’s theorem of connectivity of spectral graph partitions). The two subgraphs resulting from spectral graph partitioning on a connected graph are also connected.

The proof is available in [31, Corollary 2.9]. To derive a n𝑛n-partition, one can implement spectral graph partitioning recursively n𝑛n times. Since we aim for subgraphs with similar size, each iteration applies spectral graph partitioning on the subgraph with the largest number of nodes. The most computationally expensive step in this process is the eigenvector computation, which only takes linear time, or 𝒪​(n)𝒪𝑛\mathcal{O}(n). This low complexity is reflected on the negligible computational time in our simulations. Even though this recursive spectral partitioning does not in general lead to an n𝑛n-optimal partition, we can characterize a lower bound for the sum of weights for each iteration l𝑙l of the recursive partitioning by

12​Copt,l2≤∑{i,k}∈ℰc,lA​(i,k),12superscriptsubscript𝐶opt𝑙2subscript𝑖𝑘subscriptℰ𝑐𝑙𝐴𝑖𝑘\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}C_{\operatorname{opt},l}^{2}\leq\sum_{\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{c,l}}A(i,k), (23)

where Copt,lsubscript𝐶opt𝑙C_{\operatorname{opt},l} is the optimal value for 222-optimal partitioning and ℰc,lsubscriptℰ𝑐𝑙\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{c,l} is the edge cut set in iteration l𝑙l (without loss of generality, we have assume A𝐴A is normalized). Inequality (23) follows directly from Cheeger inequalities [32] and the Courant-Fischer Theorem [33].

This problem is a variant of (P2) that is convenient for the reconstruction of the solution of (P2) over the original 𝒢𝒢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}. Notice that (P4) is still NP-hard due to αi​ksubscript𝛼𝑖𝑘\alpha_{ik}, but the number of switches |ℰs,i|subscriptℰ𝑠𝑖|\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s,i}| in each partition is less than |ℰs|subscriptℰ𝑠|\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}|, and decreases with n𝑛n. The addition of 𝒫l,isubscript𝒫𝑙𝑖\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}_{l,i} and 𝒬l,isubscript𝒬𝑙𝑖\operatorname{\mathcal{Q}}_{l,i} in (P4) accounts for the coupling between 𝒢⁡[𝒱l]𝒢subscript𝒱𝑙\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}[\operatorname{\mathcal{V}}_{l}] and the other subgraphs. For each subgraph, these terms are constant and do not provide an exact approximation of the power exchanged between the subgraphs – since they do not take into account the dependency of the terminal voltage on the solutions determined on the other subgraphs. Therefore, putting together the solutions obtained for each subgraph may not result in a feasible solution of (P2), but rather a solution to (P2) with a perturbation on (6c). We address this next.

V-4 Full SDP optimization with fixed topology

In the last step, we define the candidate optimal switch αpopt∈{0,1}|ℰs|superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑝optsuperscript01subscriptℰ𝑠\alpha_{p}^{\operatorname{opt}}\in\{0,1\}^{|\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}|} from the solutions of (P4) obtained in the previous step. With this in place, we solve (P1)-αpoptsubscriptsuperscript𝛼opt𝑝\alpha^{\operatorname{opt}}_{p} to obtain the candidate optimal solution Wpoptsubscriptsuperscript𝑊opt𝑝W^{\operatorname{opt}}_{p} and output (αpopt,Wpopt)subscriptsuperscript𝛼opt𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑊opt𝑝(\alpha^{\operatorname{opt}}_{p},W^{\operatorname{opt}}_{p}) as the reconstructed solution of (P2).

VI Simulation Studies

In this section we illustrate the performance of the virtual-voltage approximation and the partition-based OTS algorithm on standard IEEE test systems. All simulations are done on a desktop with 3.5GHz CPU and 16GB RAM, using MATLAB and its CVX toolbox [34] to solve the convex optimization problems. In all our tables except the last row in Table III, “lower bound” refers to the optimal value of (P3) and “upper bound” refers to the optimal value of (P1)-α𝛼\alpha, where α𝛼\alpha is determined by the corresponding method.

VI-A Comparison with McCormick Relaxation

We implement the virtual-voltage approximation and compare its performance against the solution obtained from (P2) with the McCormick approximation (cf. Remark IV.7). For the latter, we use two different estimates on the upper bounds of the line power flows. In one case, we use the conservative bounds P¯i​k=−P¯i​k=5subscript¯𝑃𝑖𝑘subscript¯𝑃𝑖𝑘5\overline{P}_{ik}=-\underline{P}_{ik}=5(p.u.) and Q¯i​k=−Q¯i​k=5subscript¯𝑄𝑖𝑘subscript¯𝑄𝑖𝑘5\overline{Q}_{ik}=-\underline{Q}_{ik}=5(p.u.) for all {i,k}∈ℰ^s𝑖𝑘subscript^ℰ𝑠\{i,k\}\in\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}_{s}. These bounds come from the heuristic estimation on the largest line active/reactive power flow. In the other case, we set the tighter bounds P¯i​k=−P¯i​k=1subscript¯𝑃𝑖𝑘subscript¯𝑃𝑖𝑘1\overline{P}_{ik}=-\underline{P}_{ik}=1(p.u.) and Q¯i​k=−Q¯i​k=0.5subscript¯𝑄𝑖𝑘subscript¯𝑄𝑖𝑘0.5\overline{Q}_{ik}=-\underline{Q}_{ik}=0.5(p.u.) for all {i,k}∈ℰ^s𝑖𝑘subscript^ℰ𝑠\{i,k\}\in\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}_{s}, based on our knowledge of the solution of the IEEE test nominal case. We include an additional cost function on the line power losses to promote optimal solutions with some edges disconnected. For each test case, a set of switchable lines are selected by the following policy: given a design parameter p∈ℕ𝑝ℕp\in\operatorname{\mathbb{N}}, we rank all lines by the norm of their admittance in ascending order and select the first p𝑝p as the set of switchable lines. The rationale for this selection is that each line with small admittance places a small correlation between its terminal nodes and, as a result, they are more likely to be disconnected. The selection of p𝑝p is based on the size of the network.

The virtual-voltage approach yields discrete variables close to {0,1}01\{0,1\} for all the test cases and, in contrast, the McCormick relaxation has most of them around 0.50.50.5. Table I shows the values obtained by both approximations, and confirms that the virtual-voltage approach gives better solutions than the McCormick relaxation. It is worthwhile to note that every virtual voltage matrix U𝑈U has its condition number comfortably more than 1000 for all the test cases. The smallest condition number is 1492. This validates the statements of Lemma IV.1 and Remark IV.2 for a physically meaningful virtual voltage.

In both the McCormick relaxation and virtual-voltage methods, the number of decision variables grows linearly with respect to p𝑝p. Though p𝑝p is relatively small compared to the dimension of W𝑊W and is not the main factor for optimization complexity, we observe in Table II that for a given p𝑝p, the McCormick relaxation returns a solution noticeably faster than the virtual-voltage method. The reason is that the McCormick relaxation does not introduce LMIs for the switchable lines. In this regard, the virtual-voltage approach trades time complexity for better-quality solutions.

VI-B Comparison with BARON

We compare the virtual-voltage approximation with the general purpose mixed-integer nonlinear programming solver BARON [36] in several small-scale IEEE examples. With the default settings and maximal computational time at 1000 seconds, BARON does not always return a feasible solution, see Table III.

We observe that BARON gives a feasible solution only when it finds one in the preprocessing stage, which happens for the IEEE 30 bus test case and the IEEE 39 bus test case with one switchable line. The branch-and-bound process made in BARON only slowly increases the lower bound, and barely refines the upper bound given in the preprocessing stage. On top of discrete binary variables for switching, OTS involves nonlinearities coming from bilinear products. All these factors can prevent general purpose solvers such as BARON from finding the optimal solution efficiently. On the other hand, the virtual-voltage approximation is built on provably accurate SDP relaxations of OPF and makes use of the specific structure of the OTS problem. Table III clearly shows the difference in performance between both methods.

VI-C Partition-based OTS algorithm

We examine here the performance of the partition-based algorithm. Table IV shows the result of implementing on the IEEE 118 and IEEE 300 bus test cases the following methods: (i) the virtual-voltage approximation with 40 switchable lines; and (ii) the partition-based OTS algorithm with 404040 switchable lines; and (iii) the virtual-voltage approximation with all the lines switchable. For the case with 40 switchable lines, one can see that the partition-based OTS algorithm refines the virtual-voltage approximation. The solutions obtained by the virtual-voltage approximation and the partition-based OTS algorithm with 40 switchable lines are both close to the lower bound. In addition, SDP returns a rank-1 solution for every case with 40 switchable lines. We quantify their accuracy by upper bounding the percentage error with the true optimal solution using (p1opt−p3,allopt)/p3,allopt⋅100%⋅subscriptsuperscript𝑝opt1subscriptsuperscript𝑝opt3allsubscriptsuperscript𝑝opt3allpercent100(p^{\operatorname{opt}}_{1}-p^{\operatorname{opt}}_{3,\text{all}})/{p^{\operatorname{opt}}_{3,\text{all}}}\cdot 100\%.

We simulate case (iii) where all the lines are switchable to compare the results with the QC relaxation method [15]. The QC relaxation method takes 10 hours to solve the OTS problem for both IEEE 118 and 300 bus test cases employing servers with 4334 CPUs and 64GB memory. The QC relaxation method converges to a near optimum with around 1%percent11\% error for the IEEE 118 test case, while it is unable to provide a feasible solution for the IEEE 300 bus case. In contrast, solving (P3) with all lines switchable takes significantly less time for both cases (around 2min30sec and 1h30min, respectively) as shown in Table IV. Though we only retrieve a rank-2 solution from (P3) for IEEE 118 bus case, the condition number of the decision variable W𝑊W is larger than 250, which translates to an error (or violation of constraints) less than 1%percent11\%. Therefore, the virtual-voltage approximation leads to a solution of a similar quality as QC. The reason of not retrieving a rank-1 solution with the virtual-voltage approximation is that it provides high-rank solutions when the U𝑈U matrix is introduced on every line (this is one of the reasons for pre-selecting a subset of lines).

VI-D OTS with Security Constraints

We also validate the virtual-voltage approximation method on OTS with security constraints. We simulate both IEEE 118 and 300 bus test systems with one contingency scenario and 40 pre-selected switchable lines. Table V shows the results for the IEEE 118 bus test system with security constraint on line {106,107}106107\{106,107\}. The combined computational time in computing the lower and upper bounds raises to 834 (395+438) seconds, which is longer than the one without security constraint (149.37 seconds in Table IV). For the IEEE 300 bus test case, CVX cannot find a feasible solution even when we increase the maximal iterations to 600600600 (the default is 100100100 iterations), which took around 3.7 hours. The drastic increase on the computational time limits the applicability of the SDP-based approach to OTS with security constraints.

VII Conclusions

We have considered OTS problems with security constraints. For these scenarios, the standard SDP relaxation of the problem remains non-convex because of the presence of bilinear terms and the discrete variables. We have proposed an approximation based on the introduction of virtual-voltages to convexify the bilinear terms. We have also characterized several of its properties regarding physical interpretation and lower and upper bounds on the optimal value of the original problem. To handle the presence of the discrete variables, we have built on the virtual-voltage approximation to propose a graph partition-based algorithm that significantly reduces the computational complexity of solving the original problem. The high degree of accuracy and the reduction in computational complexity observed in simulations makes the proposed algorithms promising for OTS applications. Future work will incorporate other types of discrete controls, and investigate distributed methods for general mixed-integer OPF problems.
